intro: Neonavajoa peeblesiana subsp. fickeisenii, commonly known as the Desert Evening Primrose, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its showy yellow flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and thrives in arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and hairy, adapted to reduce water loss in hot, dry climates. The species is part of the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is known for its ecological importance in desert ecosystems.
